grammarModel.structure

Interface ISyntacticStructure

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    IAlternation, IRule, ISymmetry, ISyntacticBranch, ISyntacticGrove, ISyntacticLeaf, ITermOrVarValue, IValueOrRelation
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AlternationRule, AlternationRulE, ArithSeq, ArithSeQ, BouncingCycle, BouncingCyclE, Center, CenteR, Cycle, CyclE, Digit, DigiT, Enumeration, EnumeratioN, EveryXElem, EveryXEleM, FirstValue, FirstValuE, Increment, IncremenT, NoAlterN, Position, PositioN, ReflectedPart, ReflectedParT, Relation, RelatioN, Size, SizE, StartAt, StartAT, Symmetry, SymmetrY, SymmetryWithCenter, SymmetryWithCenteR, SyntacticBranch, SyntacticGrove, SyntacticLeaf, SyntacticStructure, Value, ValuE

    public interface ISyntacticStructure
extends java.lang.Cloneable
    ISyntacticStructure is an abstract class that is used to represent the nodes of a syntactic tree. The composition relationship between ISyntacticStructure objects is an equivalent to the derivation relationship between nodes of a syntactic tree. Therefore, ISyntacticStructure can be extended in order to represent : 1/ a syntactic tree terminal node (or 'syntactic leaf') 2/ the derivation from a non-terminal node ('syntactic branch') 3/ a whole syntactic tree (also a 'syntactic branch', but whose name is the start element of the context-free grammar at use) 4/ a list of syntactic trees (called a 'syntactic glove').
    Author:
    Gael Tregouet

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        java.lang.String getName()
        Returns:
        the name (or type) of this structure, which is also the name of the generating node in the syntactic tree from which its components are derived : it therefore refers to a grammatical element of the context-free grammar at use. Two different syntactic structures can have the same name if this name is a non-terminal element (or 'variable') of the context-free grammar that can lead to different derivations.

      • getSyntacticChains

        ISyntacticChains getSyntacticChains()
                             throws GrammarModelException
        Returns:
        a list of chains that contains all the spanning paths of the syntactic structure (from its generating node to one of its terminals).
        Throws:
        GrammarModelException

      • getSetOfSyntacticChains

        java.util.Set<ISyntacticChains> getSetOfSyntacticChains()
                                                 throws GrammarModelException
        Returns:
        the set of spanning paths associated with this structure, plus all the sets associated with any of its components, sub-components. etc.
        Throws:
        GrammarModelException

      • getPosetMaxChains

        IPosetMaxChains getPosetMaxChains()
                           throws GrammarModelException
        Returns:
        the set of spanning chains of the poset (lower semilattice) that can be derived from this syntactic structure.
        Throws:
        GrammarModelException
        See Also:
        IOriginalPropertyPoset

      • getImplications

        java.util.Set<IImplication> getImplications()
                                     throws GrammarModelException
        Returns:
        the set of implications associated with the poset (lower semilattice) that can be derived from this syntactic structure.
        Throws:
        GrammarModelException
        See Also:
        IPosetMaxChains

      • isRedundant

        boolean isRedundant()
        A syntactic structure R is redundant if it is a component of a structure A, and if another component of A contains a similar structure R'. Put another way : a syntactic structure R is redundant if it is a component of a structure A, and if the string of terminals generated by R is included in the string of terminal generated by another component of A.
        Returns:
        true if this structure is redundant.

      • markRedundancies

        void markRedundancies()
        Looks for redundancies in this structure components, sub-components, etc. A syntactic structure R is redundant if it is a component of a structure A, and if another component of A contains a similar structure R'. Put another way : a syntactic structure R is redundant if it is a component of a structure A, and if the string of terminals generated by R is included in the string of terminal generated by another component of A.

      • setAsRedundant

        void setAsRedundant()
        Marks this structure and all its potential components, sub-components, etc., as redundant. A syntactic structure R is redundant if it is a component of a structure A, and if another component of A contains a similar structure R'. Put another way : a syntactic structure R is redundant if it is a component of a structure A, and if the string of terminals generated by R is included in the string of terminal generated by another component of A.

      • clone

        ISyntacticStructure clone()

      • getPosetElementName

        java.lang.String getPosetElementName()
                              throws GrammarModelException
        A 'poset element name' is used to generate the property poset spanning chains from the syntactic structure, and ultimately the property poset itself. It is a concatenation of the syntactic element 'name' with an index generated to assure that that structures belonging to the same 'syntactic glove' can't return the same 'poset element name' if they don't have the same components. Put another way : two nodes from syntactic trees belonging to the same glove (and possibly having the same name) can't generate the same 'poset element name' if they don't also generate the same derivation.
        Returns:
        a 'poset element name'.
        Throws:
        GrammarModelException
        See Also:
        IPosetMaxChains, IOriginalPropertyPoset

      • getListOfComponents

        java.util.List<ISyntacticStructure> getListOfComponents()
        Returns:
        the list of component structures. The composition relationship between ISyntacticStructure objects being an equivalent to the derivation relationship between nodes of a syntactic tree, component structures represent the nodes of a syntactic tree that are directly derived from the generating node of this structure (the one that gives this structure its name).

      • getListOfSyntacticStringChains

        java.util.List<java.util.List<java.lang.String>> getListOfSyntacticStringChains()
        Returns:
        a list of lists of strings, representing all the spanning paths of the syntactic structure (leading from its generating node to one of its terminals).

      • getListOfPosetMaxStringChains

        java.util.List<java.util.List<java.lang.String>> getListOfPosetMaxStringChains()
                                                                        throws GrammarModelException
        Returns:
        a list of lists of strings, representing the set of spanning chains of the poset (lower semilattice) that can be derived from this syntactic structure.
        Throws:
        GrammarModelException

      • getListOfLeafIDs

        java.util.List<java.lang.Long> getListOfLeafIDs()
        Returns:
        the list of IDs associated with every syntactic leaf that can be derived from this structure's generating node. (All syntactic leaves have a leafID).

      • getStringOfTerminals

        java.lang.String getStringOfTerminals()
        Returns:
        a concatenation (with a separator) of the chain of syntactic leaves (or terminals) that can be derived from this structure's generating node. If the node is itself a terminal (because the structure is a syntactic leaf), its name is returned.

      • getIDHasBeenSet

        boolean getIDHasBeenSet()
        Returns:
        true if this structure has been provided with an ID, and can subsequently generate a 'poset element name'.

      • hasThisProperty

        boolean hasThisProperty(java.lang.String prop)
        Parameters:
        prop - property name, referring to an element of the context-free grammar at use.
        Returns:
        true if the parameter is the name of this structure generating node, or the name of any derived node in the syntactic tree.

      • setPosetElementID

        void setPosetElementID(java.util.Map<ISyntacticChains,java.lang.String> chainsToIndex)
                throws GrammarModelException
        Provides this structure (and its components, sub-components, etc.) with a 'poset element ID', mapped with its generated list of chains.
        Parameters:
        chainsToIndex - a map that associates syntactic chains with a unique ID.
        Throws:
        GrammarModelException
        See Also:
        ISyntacticGrove

      • replaceComponents

        boolean replaceComponents(ISyntacticStructure newComp,
                          java.util.List<java.lang.Long> compIDs)
        Replaces a target leaf component by a new component. Syntactic tree growth involves the replacement of leaves by new branches (or, rarely, by new leaves). These new components are injected in the structure whith the IDs of the leaf they are meant to replace. If one of the structure component is a target leaf, then it is replaced ; otherwise, the same method is recursively called on every non-terminal component, with the same parameters.
        Parameters:
        newComp - new syntactic component
        compIDs - IDs of the leaves to be replaced
        Returns:
        true if a replacement has occurred.
